headline: OHSU releases lengthy defense of primate research center amid calls for closure | kgw.com
context: The facility has come under fire due to concerns about animal suffering, but OHSU argues that the research saves human lives and can't be replaced.

PORTLAND, Ore. — OHSU released a lengthy statement this week pushing back on accusations of mistreatment at the hospital's Oregon National Primate Research Center, responding to a recent TV and social media ad campaign from the nonprofit Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine (PCRM) that calls for the facility to be closed down.

annotations.paragraph: The center has come under increasing fire amid reports of accidents and accusations of animal mistreatment, but OHSU has rebuffed calls to shut it down, arguing that the facility employs hundreds of people and carries out life-saving research into new vaccines and treatments for chronic diseases — studies that it says cannot be carried out without animal testing.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides essential context about the controversy and OHSU's defense of the research center.

annotations.paragraph: PCRM and the group People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) have been among the most prominent critics of OHSU's animal research practices in recent years. PCRM began campaigning against the hospital's use of pigs for surgical training in 2022, and PETA won a lawsuit against OHSU in 2023 for concealing videos of animal experiments.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant information about the critics and legal actions against OHSU.

annotations.paragraph: The primate center in particular came under scrutiny after InvestigateWest reported in 2023 that of the seven monkey research facilities in the U.S., the OHSU center had the most Animal Welfare Act Violations from 2014 to 2022, including an accident that killed two monkeys in 2020 — an incident which also sparked a legislative push for more transparency.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific details about the violations and incidents at the center.

annotations.paragraph: PCRM began running its campaign in February, and Willamette Week and The Oregonian reported in March that activists were calling on Gov. Tina Kotek to make the closure a precondition for OHSU's pending merger with Legacy Health. Kotek likely doesn't have that authority, but both papers reported that she did urge OHSU to wind down the facility.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides information on the political and activist actions related to the center's closure.

annotations.paragraph: PETA announced this week that it would step up its own efforts by setting up a travelling exhibit outside OHSU called "How the Other Half Lives." The group said the exhibit, presented as a 7-foot-tall pair of binoculars, will contrast the conditions in research labs with the living conditions of monkeys in the wild.
annotations.reason: This paragraph describes PETA's new campaign efforts against the research center.

annotations.paragraph: "Through these lenses, the public sees what OHSU carefully hides; monkeys trapped in barren metal cages barely bigger than their own bodies, living in fear, and discarded like used paper towels, while their wild kin thrive in rich forests, surrounded by family," Dr. Lisa Jones-Engel of PETA said in a statement. "PETA urges OHSU to end this cruelty, shut down its failed primate center, and shift to modern, animal-free research methods."
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a direct quote from PETA, which is relevant to the controversy surrounding the primate research center.

annotations.paragraph: OHSU's latest statement reiterates many of the hospital's previous responses about the contributions that the research facility has made to human medical science. The statement doesn't name PCRM or PETA, but presents a series of rebuttals to their criticisms.
annotations.reason: This paragraph summarizes OHSU's defense and response to criticisms, which is central to the article's focus.

annotations.paragraph: In response to claims that the facility's funding could be spent on patient care, OHSU said the vast majority of the facility's funding takes the forms of research grants from the National Institutes of Health (NIH), along with some philanthropic sources, so the money can't be reassigned.
annotations.reason: This paragraph addresses financial aspects of the controversy, providing specific information about funding sources.

annotations.paragraph: Closing the facility would also cost an estimated $100 million, OHSU said, in part because selling off the property would require NIH approval, which would "likely limit the proceeds available to OHSU."
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific financial implications of closing the facility, relevant to the article's main topic.

annotations.paragraph: Addressing concerns about animal cruelty, OHSU said that most of its animals live in outdoor family groups and receive excellent medical and dental care. Research animals also receive pain relief medication for painful procedures, OHSU said, adding that its researchers "cannot eliminate all pain but seek to diminish pain and distress to the greatest extent possible."
annotations.reason: This paragraph directly addresses the animal cruelty concerns, which are central to the calls for the facility's closure.

annotations.paragraph: Regarding the previous animal care incidents, OHSU stressed the heavily regulated nature of animal medical research, which limits its use to carefully reviewed studies with high scientific value for human health care. The hospital said it's required to report all incidents to regulators and conduct an analysis afterwards to avoid future risks.
annotations.reason: Provides specific information about regulations and procedures related to animal care incidents.

annotations.paragraph: Turning to the argument that animal research is outdated or no longer needed, OHSU replied that there still aren't animal-free research options available for studying conditions like Alzheimer's and Parkinson's, as well as some infectious diseases and reproductive health — and monkey research in particular is critical because the results can directly translate to humans.
annotations.reason: Addresses a key argument against animal research and provides specific examples of conditions that require it.

annotations.paragraph: The hospital also said it limits the use of primates to the smallest number possible and is working toward eliminating their involvement altogether, but the technology "isn't there yet" and continued primate research is necessary in the meantime, including to test and develop eventual alternative methods.
annotations.reason: Explains efforts to reduce primate use and the necessity of current research.

annotations.paragraph: The statement was posted alongside a separate news release featuring testimonials from some of the doctors and researchers at the facility, highlighting some of the new treatments, techniques and medical knowledge that they've been able to develop.
annotations.reason: Mentions testimonials and developments but lacks specific details or new information.
